block.p: More Terror Attacks in Iraq Were Averted, U.S. Says An American military commander said his men had foiled additional terrorist attacks that were to accompany those that killed as many as 185 people on Tuesday. Leaders of Iraqi political parties demanded that their private militias play a greater role in policing the country.

Tracking Global Terror Network Investigators were able to monitor the conversations and movements of several Qaeda leaders and dozens of operatives for two years after determining that the suspects favored a particular brand of cellphone chip.

American intelligence agencies have doubled or even tripled the number of Arabic and Farsi speakers on their payrolls since the Sept. 11 attacks, but more are needed.

Additional Scandal for Sharon An Israeli newspaper questioned Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's motives for approving a lopsided prisoner exchange in January that freed more than 400 Arabs in return for an Israeli man kidnapped while pursuing a dubious business venture.

Terror Threats Alarm France An unknown terrorist entity has threatened to explode bombs throughout the French railway system unless more than $5 million is paid. The plot has traumatized the French government, and the police.

Haitian Leader Calls for Unity United States marines entered Port-au-Prince, and the rebel leader, Guy Philippe, announced that he would disarm his men and leave. The country's interim president, Boniface Alexandre, spoke to the nation for the first time since Jean-Bertrand Aristide fled, urging Haitians to unite in defusing the crisis.

Delay Seen on Migrants President Vicente Fox of Mexico said that he did not expect the United States to adopt reforms that would give legal status to millions of undocumented workers until after the presidential election.

Bush Starts Ad Push; Kerry Campaigns in Florida The Bush campaign announced the start of what may be the most expensive advertising campaign in presidential history, with commercials devised to erase months of Democratic attacks by portraying President Bush as a plain-spoken leader who steadied the nation after the 2001 terrorist attacks.
Senator John Kerry began his general election campaign rallying voters in the battleground state of Florida and naming a financier to oversee his search for a running mate.

Mad Cow Investigation Begins The government has begun a criminal investigation into whether documents were falsified in the only case of mad cow disease found in the United States, the Agriculture Department's inspector general said.

Ozone Law Exemptions The United States is seeking to make more American farmers and industries exempt from a treaty that will ban a popular pesticide that damages the ozone layer, Bush administration officials said.

Separate but Equal Classrooms The administration has proposed regulations giving public school districts new freedom to create same-sex classes and schools if ''substantially equal'' opportunities are provided for the excluded sex.

Attorney General Issues Mixed Report on Marriage New York State law requires same-sex marriages that are legally performed in other states to be recognized as lawful in New York, but does not now permit such marriages to be performed in the state, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said in a legal opinion.

Republican leaders in the United States Senate said they would aggressively pursue a constitutional amendment banning gay marriages, but partisan divisions emerged as Democrats accused them of creating a false air of crisis.
Shortly after being arraigned on misdemeanor charges, Mayor Jason West of New Paltz, N.Y., said he would continue solemnizing same-sex marriages.
New York City's Law Department told the city clerk that gay couples should be denied marriage licenses as City Council members and gay groups pressured Mayor Bloomberg to take a position.
Oregon's most populous county began issuing marriage licenses to exultant same-sex couples.

Testimony in Williams Case Benoit Benjamin, a former pro basketball teammate of Jayson Williams, testified that he saw Williams's finger on the trigger of a shotgun just before the gun fired, killing a chauffeur.
Challenging Show on Amish Amish and others have started a campaign to stop a UPN show in which Amish teenagers face the shock of the big city.

Eisner Stripped of Post The board of Walt Disney stripped Michael D. Eisner of the chairmanship and give it to George J. Mitchell, a former senator, after shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent the company withheld their support to re-elect him to the board.

Shell Chief Forced to Resign Sir Philip Watts, the top executive of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, was forced to resign after an internal investigation into the company's surprise disclosure in January that it had overstated its oil and natural-gas reserves by 20 percent.

U.S. Seeks Tax Client Names A law firm that sold what the government says were abusive tax shelters participated in fraud and should not be allowed to hide the identities of its tax shelter clients from the Internal Revenue Service, the Justice Department contends in court papers.
